meanings.definition: To cause harm or injury to someone's rights or interests.
meanings.sent1: By prejudicing the case, the lawyer made it difficult for the defendant to receive a fair trial.
meanings.sent2: The biased judge was prejudicing the outcome of the trial by favoring one side.
meanings.sent3: The cat was prejudicing the dog's chances of getting treats by stealing them all.
meanings.sent4: The storm was prejudicing the fragile roof, causing it to leak.
meanings.sent5: The bully's actions were prejudicing the victim's sense of safety and well-being.

meanings.definition: To have a harmful effect on someone's opinion or judgment.
meanings.sent1: Her negative comments were prejudicing my view of the movie before I even watched it.
meanings.sent2: The misleading advertisement was prejudicing customers into buying a product that didn't work as promised.
meanings.sent3: The loud music was prejudicing my ability to concentrate on my homework.
meanings.sent4: The constant gossiping was prejudicing her reputation among her peers.
meanings.sent5: The biased news report was prejudicing the public's perception of the event.

meanings.definition: To influence someone unfairly or negatively.
meanings.sent1: The false rumors were prejudicing her classmates against her.
meanings.sent2: The competitive coworker was prejudicing the boss's opinion of her work.
meanings.sent3: The broken clock was prejudicing their ability to tell time accurately.
meanings.sent4: The harsh criticism was prejudicing his self-esteem and confidence.
meanings.sent5: The biased article was prejudicing readers to believe false information.
